newsitem.title: USA: NYC sees another $1.7 bln capital need thru 2001.
newsitem.headline: NYC sees another $1.7 bln capital need thru 2001.

text.p: New York City will need to spend about $1.7 billion on capital projects through fiscal 2001 beyond amounts already projected for the period, city officials said Thursday.

"By June 30, 2001, the current forecasts indicate an additional need for capital programs financing capacity beyond that currently forecast for the city's general obligation and statutorily authorized finance authority capacity, of $1.7 billion," the city's budget director, Joseph Lhota, said in a letter concerning the city's statement of debt affordability.

Asked if the new projections meant the city had changed its capital program in the mayor's new 1998 fiscal budget, a city official replied: "The short answer is no change." The official declined to be named.
New York City's new Transitional Finance Authority is authorized to issue $7.5 billion of bonds, an amount that, prior to the new forecast, had been expected to last about four years.
